content.rendered:
So sorry. Im just a lowly test page.

Ill be deleted soon. Or at least: never leave the dev environement.

My template file will even be deleted

And this tekst probably wont even be displayed anywhere – unless it ends up in the menu, I guess.

content.rendered:
Dette er en eksempelside. Den er forskjellig fra et blogginnlegg fordi den blir på ett sted og vil vises i navigasjonsmenyen (i de fleste temaer). De fleste starter med en «Om meg»-side som introduserer dem for potensielle besøkende. Der kan det stå noe som dette:

Hei! Jeg er sykkelbud om dagen, en aspirerende skuespiller om kvelden og dette er min blogg. Jeg bor i Bergen, har en kul hund som heter Biff og liker karsk.

…eller noe som dette:

Ditt-og-datt-selskapet ble grunnlagt i 1971, og har produsert både ditt og datt helt siden da. Selskapet holder til i Vassenden, rett forbi Jølstravatn. Vi har over 2000 ansatte og gjør alt mulig fantastisk for samfunnet i Vassenden.

Som ny WordPress-bruker burde du gå til ditt kontrollpanel for å slette denne siden og lage nye sider for ditt innhold. Lykke til!

title.rendered: React: Replace jQuery $.get with regular JavaScript

content.rendered:
Fist up against the wall is jQuery, that friendly and helpful open-source project who most certainly didn’t mean any harm.

componentDidMount: function() {
var connection = new XMLHttpRequest();
connection.open(«GET», ‘wp-content/themes/reactionary/assets/content/posts.json’, true);
connection.send();
connection.onreadystatechange = function() {
if (connection.readyState==4 && connection.status==200) {
var result = JSON.parse(connection.responseText);
if (this.isMounted()) {
this.setState({
menu: result.menu.posts,
primary: result.primary.posts,
secondary: result.secondary.posts,
titles: [result.menu.title, result.primary.title, result.secondary.title],
});
}
}
}.bind(this);
},

That lets us drop jQuery, and well, every millisecond counts. The page loads 250 to 300 ms faster now – that’s a quarter second, a big chunk given that the target is less than a second in load time.

excerpt.rendered: Fist up against the wall is jQuery, that friendly and helpful open-source project who most certainly didn’t mean any harm.

content.rendered:
You want your site to be faster than the blink of an eye.

Like – BOOM, it’s there.

Blink, and you miss it. You want it to be surprisingly fast.

So let’s do that. Let’s find out just how fast a really fast website can get.

excerpt.rendered:
Google wants sites to load in a second or less.
That’s way too slow.

content.rendered:
I’ve been developing web sites for a very long time now, pretty much ever sisce the web first appeared back in the mid-nineties. I’ve seen trends and technologies come and go. Most developments in web design is beneficial for the user eperience, and some of it is downright neccecary, like the transition to responsive design a few years ago. That was neccecary because mobile devices was getting so prolific; not the big phone is the dominant browser size.

Currently, flat design is the dominant design trend, and it nice I guess. It’s clean.

But it’s just so boring!

Flat design bores my socks of. Pretty much all my clients want minimalist, flat designs, and that’s what they get, of course. But it is just so boring!

I like colours.
I like weird fonts.
I like quirky and interesting.

Flat design is the epitome of everything I like about the web. Sure, it works; it’s functoional. But it does not inspire me. It doesnt do anything for me.

In most cases that’s fine. But now that I’m making a personal blog/portfolio, I decided to go in a different direction – a mesh of design and technology that represents my views and sensibilities better. I’m not a flat person: I’m an opinionated, pun-loving veteran of the browser wars, a web pioneer and a stubborn old codger who likes gadgets. I’m anything but flat, so why should my web site be?

So I made this little manifesto about how I’d prefer to make web sites. Here goes:

 

Be fast

I don’t have time to wait for websites to load. When I click something, things had better start moving instantly, and I don’t mean those litter spinner icons indicating that somethings loading in the background. No – I mean blink and you miss it fast. Everything should be built around fast load times, because sluggish web pages are the worst. It’s like finding sand and hair in your food. Be fast. If a site only gets to have one super power, that should be super speed. Everything else is secondary.

Be fresh

Follow standars, but don’t support old tech. People can afford a new browser; they’re free. It’s time to cut the old junk loose and let it sink to the bottom of the ocean.

Burn the libraries

Don’t use libraries and front end libraries because they’re easy to use. Sure, jQuery is convenient. But it’s also uneccecary and slow. Ditch anything you can. I love ZURB Foundation and Twitter Bootstrap and some other frameworks too, they’re great for productivity but not neccecary. Drop them if you can.

React is pretty awesome, though.

I love React, so it’s exempt from the «No libraries» rule. Plus, React offers something unique, it has real value. So React is in. In fact, it’s a cornerstone for the whole site.

… Listen, I have to get back to coding, I’ll update this manifesto later.

excerpt.rendered: I’ve been developing web sites for a very long time now, pretty much ever sisce the web first appeared back in the mid-nineties. I’ve seen trends and technologies come and go. Most developments in web design is beneficial for the user eperience, and some of it is downright neccecary, like the transition to responsive design […]
